en_first_half: Miss Watson she kept pecking at me, and it got tiresome and lonesome. By-and-by they fetched the niggers in and had prayers, and then everybody was off to bed. I went up to my room with a piece of candle, and put it on the table. Then I set down in a chair by the window and tried to think of something cheerful, but it warn’t no use. I felt so lonesome I most wished I was dead. The stars were shining, and the leaves rustled in the woods ever so mournful; and I heard an owl, away off, who-whooing about somebody that was dead, and a whippowill and a dog crying about somebody that was going to die; and the wind was trying to whisper something to me, and I couldn’t make out what it was, and so it made the cold shivers run over me. Then away out in the woods I heard that kind of a sound that a ghost makes when it wants to tell about something that’s on its mind and can’t
en_second_half: make itself understood, and so can’t rest easy in its grave, and has to go about that way every night grieving. I got so down-hearted and scared I did wish I had some company. Pretty soon a spider went crawling up my shoulder, and I flipped it off and it lit in the candle; and before I could budge it was all shriveled up. I didn’t need anybody to tell me that that was an awful bad sign and would fetch me some bad luck, so I was scared and most shook the clothes off of me. I got up and turned around in my tracks three times and crossed my breast every time; and then I tied up a little lock of my hair with a thread to keep witches away. But I hadn’t no confidence. You do that when you’ve lost a horseshoe that you’ve found, instead of nailing it up over the door, but I hadn’t ever heard anybody say it was any way to keep off bad luck when you’d killed a spider.

en_results_raw: <output>The sound was a low, mournful moan, and it seemed to be coming from a great distance away. I strained my ears to listen, but it was hard to make out what it was saying. It sounded like a sigh, a long, drawn-out sigh that seemed to be filled with a deep sadness. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I listened, and I couldn't help but wonder what it could be. Was it a spirit, trying to communicate with me? Or was it just the wind, playing tricks on my ears? I sat there for a long time, trying to make out what the sound was, but it seemed to fade away into the darkness. I was left sitting there, feeling more lonesome than ever, with only the sound of the crickets and the rustling of the leaves to keep me company. The candle on the table cast flickering shadows on the wall, making it seem like the very spirits of the dead were dancing around me. I tried to shake off the feeling of unease that had settled over me, but it was no use. I was trapped in a world of darkness and uncertainty, with only my imagination to keep me company. The more I sat there, the more I felt like I was being watched, and the sound of the wind whispering in my ear seemed to grow louder, more urgent. I knew I had to do something, but what? I couldn't just sit there forever, listening to the whispers of the wind and the moans of the unknown. I had to take action, but what action? I thought about getting out of bed and going downstairs, but something held me back. Maybe it was fear, maybe it was curiosity, but whatever it was, it kept me rooted to the spot. I sat there, frozen in indecision, as the darkness closed in around me. And then, just as I was starting to drift off to sleep, I heard it again - the sound of the wind whispering in my ear, this time more clearly than before. It was a name, a single word that seemed to be calling out to me. "Tom..." it whispered, the sound echoing through the darkness like a cold, dead breath. I sat up straight, my heart racing with fear, and I knew that I had to get out of there, and fast. I threw off the covers and got out of bed, my bare feet padding softly on the floor as I made my way to the door. I turned the handle and pushed it open, and a cold draft of air swept in, carrying with it the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves. I stepped out into the night, my eyes scanning the darkness for any sign of what was out there. The wind was howling around me, making it hard to hear anything else, but I knew I had to keep moving. I took a deep breath and started to walk, my feet carrying me further and further away from the house, until I was lost in the darkness, with only the sound of the wind to guide me. And then, just as I thought I was alone, I heard it again - the sound of the wind whispering in my ear, this time more clearly than before. "Tom..." it whispered, the sound echoing through the darkness like a cold, dead breath. I knew then that I was not alone, and that something was out there, watching me, waiting for me. I quickened my pace, my heart pounding in my chest, as I tried to outrun the darkness that was closing in around me. But no matter how fast I walked, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being herded towards some unknown fate, one that was waiting for me just beyond the edge of the trees. And then, just as I thought I was going to collapse from fear, I saw a light in the distance - a faint, flickering glow that seemed to be calling out to me. I stumbled towards it, my heart racing with hope, and as I got closer, I saw that it was a lantern, hung from a tree branch high above the ground. It cast a warm, golden light over the surrounding trees, making them seem less menacing, less threatening. I felt a sense of relief wash over me, and I knew that I had to get to that light, to find safety in its warmth. I quickened my pace, my feet pounding the earth as I made my way towards the lantern, the wind and the darkness receding behind me. And as I reached out to grab the lantern, I felt a hand on my shoulder, a cold, clammy hand that seemed to be pulling me back. I spun around, but there was no one there. Bỗng một con nhện ở đâu nhảy đến, lồm cồm bò trên vai áo, tôi vội lấy tay búng nó đi, nó bắn ngay vào ngọn nến đang cháy, tôi chưa kíp kéo nó ra thì nó đã chết queo. Lúc đó, chẳng cần phải có ai bảo tôi rằng đó là một điều xấu và rồi tôi sẽ gặp phải rủi ro, tôi cũng đã hoảng sợ lắm rồi và cuồng quýt rũ mạnh quần áo trên người. Tôi chồm dậy, quay đi quay lại một chỗ đến ba bốn vòng, rồi lại làm dấu trước ngực rất nhiều lần. Rồi tôi lại lấy sợi dây buộc chặt mớ tóc trên đầu để làm cái bùa đuổi yêu quái đi. Nhưng rồi tôi lại cũng không tin. es_first_half: Un día la señorita Watson no paraba de meterse conmigo, y yo empecé a cansarme y a sentirme solo. Después llamaron a los negros para decir las oraciones y todo el mundo se fue a la cama. Yo me fui a mi habitación con un trozo de vela y lo puse en la mesa. Después me senté en una silla junto a la ventana y traté de pensar en algo animado, pero era inútil. Me sentía tan solo que casi me daban ganas de morirme. Las estrellas brillaban y las hojas de los árboles se rozaban con un ruido muy triste; allá lejos se oía un búho que ululaba porque se había muerto alguien y un chotacabras y un perro que gritaban que se iba a morir alguien más, y el viento trataba de decirme algo y yo no entendía lo que era, de forma que me daban calofríos. Después, allá en el bosque, oí ese ruido que hacen los fantasmas cuando quieren decir algo que están pensando y no pueden hacerse entender, de forma que no
es_second_half: pueden descansar en la tumba y tienen que pasarse toda la noche velando. Me sentí tan desanimado y con tanto miedo que tuve ganas de compañía. Luego se me subió una araña por el hombro y me la quité de encima y se cayó en la vela, y antes de que pudiera yo alargar la mano, ya estaba toda quemada. No hacía falta que me dijera nadie que aquello era de muy mal fario y que me iba a traer mala suerte, así que tuve miedo y casi me quité la ropa de golpe. Me levanté y di tres vueltas santiguándome a cada vez, y después me até un rizo del pelo con un hilo para que no se me acercaran las brujas. Pero no estaba nada seguro. Eso es lo que se hace cuando ha perdido uno una herradura que se ha encontrado, en vez de clavarla encima de la puerta, pero nunca le había oído decir a nadie que fuese la forma de que no llegara la mala suerte cuando se había matado a una araña.

tr_first_half: Bayan Watson nasihatlerini ve azarlarını peş peşe sıralarken kendimi giderek daha bitkin ve yalnız hissettim. Az sonra zenci köleleri içeri aldılar ve duaya başladılar, ardından da herkes yatağına çekildi. Bir mum alıp odama gittim ve mumu masanın üstüne koydum. Pencerenin önündeki bir sandalyeye oturup şenlendirici bir şeyler düşünmeye çalıştım, ama hiç işe yaramadı. Kendimi öyle yapayalnız hissettim ki keşke ölsem dedim. Yıldızlar ışıl ışıldı ve ormandaki yapraklar hazin hazin hışırdıyordu, uzaklarda bir baykuşun öttüğünü duydum; ölen birisinin ardından puuu-huuu diyordu; ayrıca bir çobanaldatan ile bir köpek, birinin yakında öleceğini haber vermek için feryatlar koparıyorlardı; rüzgâr da bana bir şeyler fısıldamaya çalışıyordu, ama ne olduğunu bir türlü anlayamıyordum, bu yüzden sırtımda buz gibi bir ürperti dolaştı. Ardından, ormanın derinliklerinden, bir şeyler söylemeye çalışıp da derdini bir türlü anlatamayan,
tr_second_half: kahrından mezarını terk edip her akşam etrafta dolanarak çile dolduran hayaletlerin çıkardığı türden bir ses duydum. O kadar moralim bozulmuş ve o kadar korkmuştum ki keşke yanımda biri olsaydı dedim. Kısa süre sonra bir örümcek omzumdan yukarı tırmanmaya başladı, ona bir fiske vurunca gidip mumun üstüne düştü; ben daha kılımı kıpırdatamadan kavrulup gitti. Bunun korkunç kötü bir işaret olduğunu ve bana kötü şans getireceğini başkasının söylemesine gerek yoktu, korkudan yaprak gibi titremeye başlamıştım. en_results_raw: anything about me or my family, so he asked for more information about my past and the circumstances surrounding my situation. The judge and the widow began to argue with each other, each trying to present their case in the most favorable light, but the new judge listened attentively, taking notes and asking pointed questions to clarify the details. He seemed determined to make an informed decision, one that would be in the best interest of a young girl like me, who was caught in the middle of their dispute. As the hearing continued, I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease, unsure of what the outcome would be or who would ultimately be chosen to care for me. The judge's questions probed deeper, delving into the reasons behind my mother's death and the circumstances that led to my current living situation. I tried to stay focused, but my mind wandered to the memories of my mother, and the life we had shared before everything changed. The judge's expression remained neutral, but I could sense a hint of compassion in his eyes, and I wondered if he might be the one person who could see beyond the arguments and make a decision that would truly be in my best interest. As the hearing drew to a close, the judge asked one final question, one that made my heart skip a beat: "What do you want, child?" he asked, his voice low and gentle. I hesitated, unsure of how to respond, but something inside me urged me to speak the truth. "I want to be with my father," I said, my voice barely above a whisper. The room fell silent, and I could feel the weight of the judge's gaze upon me. The widow's face turned red with anger, while the judge's expression remained unreadable. I held my breath, waiting for his response, unsure of what the future held, but determined to fight for the one thing I wanted most: a chance to be with the father I loved.

en_results_raw: The routine was monotonous, yet strangely soothing. I'd grown accustomed to the gentle rhythm of the river, the soft lapping of the water against the shore, and the occasional splash of a fish breaking the surface. My days blended together in a haze of smoke and sun, with only the occasional visit from the widow to remind me of the world beyond this idyllic existence. She'd come by with a basket of fresh bread and a stern look, scolding me for my lack of industry, but I just smiled and waved her off, content in my simple, carefree life. The rags and dirt that clung to my clothes seemed to be a badge of honor, a symbol of my rejection of the strict rules and conventions that governed the widow's household. I'd never been one for books or study, and the thought of returning to that kind of routine was almost too much to bear. As the days turned into weeks, and the weeks into months, I found myself growing more and more entrenched in this lazy, jolly existence, and I couldn't help but wonder if I'd ever be able to shake it off and return to the world beyond the river's tranquil banks.

La viuda era una mujer amable y cariñosa, que me trataba como a un hijo, y su casa era un refugio para mí, un lugar donde podía relajarme y ser yo mismo. Pero a medida que pasaban los días, comenzaba a sentir una sensación de inquietud, una sensación de que algo estaba a punto de cambiar, y no sabía qué era lo que me estaba sucediendo. La viuda me había hablado de que pronto tendría que buscar un trabajo y empezar a contribuir con algo a la casa, y yo sabía que no estaba preparado para eso, que no tenía las habilidades ni la experiencia necesarias para ganarme la vida. Me sentía aterrorizado ante la perspectiva de tener que dejar mi vida tranquila y relajada para enfrentar el mundo exterior, pero al mismo tiempo, sentía una especie de curiosidad, una sensación de que había algo más allí afuera, algo que me estaba esperando, algo que podría cambiar mi vida para siempre. en_first_half: This place was a tolerable long, steep hill or ridge about forty foot high. We had a rough time getting to the top, the sides was so steep and the bushes so thick. We tramped and clumb around all over it, and by-and-by found a good big cavern in the rock, most up to the top
en_second_half: on the side towards Illinois. The cavern was as big as two or three rooms bunched together, and Jim could stand up straight in it. It was cool in there. Jim was for putting our traps in there right away, but I said we didn’t want to be climbing up and down there all the time.
en_results: The cavern was a massive opening in the side of the hill, partially hidden by the dense foliage that surrounded it. As we stepped inside, the air grew cooler and the sounds of the forest grew muffled, replaced by the gentle dripping of water somewhere in the depths of the cavern.
en_results_raw: The cavern was a massive opening in the side of the hill, partially hidden by the dense foliage that surrounded it. As we stepped inside, the air grew cooler and the sounds of the forest grew muffled, replaced by the gentle dripping of water somewhere in the depths of the cavern. The entrance was a large, arched opening that led into a vast, dark space, the ceiling lost in darkness. We fumbled in our packs for our lanterns and lit them, casting flickering shadows on the walls as we made our way deeper into the cavern. The ground beneath our feet was dry and rocky, and we had to be careful not to slip on the loose stones. As we walked, the air grew colder and the darkness seemed to press in around us, making us feel small and insignificant. We had been walking for what felt like hours, but the darkness made it impossible to tell time. Suddenly, we heard the sound of running water, and our hearts quickened with excitement. We rounded a corner and found ourselves at the edge of a vast underground lake, its surface glinting in the light of our lanterns. The water was crystal clear, and we could see fish swimming lazily in the depths. We stood there in awe, taking in the beauty of this hidden world, and wondering what other secrets the cavern held. As we gazed out across the lake, we noticed a small wooden boat tied to a rock at the water's edge. It looked old and weathered, but it seemed sturdy enough to hold our weight. We looked at each other, and without a word, we knew what we had to do. We untied the boat and pushed off from the rock, and began to make our way across the lake, the water lapping gently against the sides of the boat as we glided across its surface. The silence was almost palpable, broken only by the sound of the water and the occasional creak of the boat's wooden hull. As we reached the far side of the lake, we found a narrow tunnel that led deeper into the cavern. We pushed the boat back into the water and climbed out, our hearts pounding with excitement. We had no idea what lay ahead, but we were determined to find out. We took a deep breath, and stepped into the unknown, the darkness swallowing us whole.

La entrada era estrecha, pero logramos entrar sin problemas y nos sentamos en el suelo, rodeados de las sombras de la roca. La oscuridad era total, pero pronto nos acostumbramos a ella y comenzamos a charlar en voz baja, intentando mantenernos calientes y secos. La lluvia creció en intensidad, golpeando la roca con fuerza y creando un ruido constante que nos hacía sentir seguros en nuestro refugio. Sin embargo, de repente, escuchamos un ruido extraño, un sonido que no parecía provenir de la lluvia ni del viento. Era un ruido bajo y profundo, como si algo estuviera moviéndose en la oscuridad de la caverna. Nos miramos entre nosotros, inquietos, y nos preguntamos qué podría ser. ¿Un animal? ¿Un sonido natural? ¿O algo más? As the sun began to set, casting a golden glow over the forest, I took a tentative bite of the roasted snake, the taste bitter and earthy on my tongue. It was a strange sensation, but I couldn't deny the sense of accomplishment I felt at having faced my fears and overcome them. I looked over at Jim, who was watching me with a mixture of concern and admiration, and nodded in appreciation for his guidance. Little did I know, this was only the beginning of our journey, and the challenges we would face would be far more daunting than a simple snake bite.

Jim liked that notion; but he said I must go in the dark and look sharp. Then he studied it over and said, couldn’t I put on some of them old things and dress up like a girl? en_second_half: hitched it behind with the hooks, and it was a fair fit. I put on the sun-bonnet and tied it under my chin, and then for a body to look in and see my face was like looking down a joint of stove-pipe. Jim said nobody would know me, even in the daytime, hardly. I practiced around all day to get the hang of the things, and by-and-by I could do pretty well in them, only Jim said I didn’t walk like a girl; and he said I must quit pulling up my gown to get at my britches-pocket. I took notice, and done better.

en_first_half: “Quick, Jim, it ain’t no time for fooling around and moaning; there’s a gang of murderers in yonder, and if we don’t hunt up their boat and set her drifting down the river so these fellows can’t get away from the wreck there’s one of
en_second_half: ’em going to be in a bad fix. But if we find their boat we can put all of ’em in a bad fix—for the Sheriff ’ll get ’em. Quick—hurry! I’ll hunt the labboard side, you hunt the stabboard. You start at the raft, and—”
en_results: The consequences of their actions will be dire, and I fear for the lives of everyone on board. We have to act fast, Jim, before they realize what's happening and make their escape. I've been keeping an eye on the river,
en_results_raw: The consequences of their actions will be dire, and I fear for the lives of everyone on board. We have to act fast, Jim, before they realize what's happening and make their escape. I've been keeping an eye on the river, and I think I see their boat moored near the old oak tree. If we can get to it before they do, we might have a chance to stop them. But we'll need to be quiet and stealthy, Jim, as we don't know how many of them there are or what kind of danger they pose. We can't afford to make any noise that might give away our position. Let's move quickly and carefully, and may our luck be with us. I'll take point and scout ahead, while you cover our backs. Stay sharp, Jim, and watch for any sign of trouble. We're running out of time, and every second counts. As we approach the boat, I can see that it's a small, rickety thing, but it'll have to do. We'll have to push it into the water and set it adrift, hoping that it'll carry the murderers away from the wreck and down the river. But what if they're not alone? What if they have accomplices waiting for them downstream? The thought sends a chill down my spine, but I push it aside and focus on the task at hand. We have to act now, Jim, before it's too late. Let's get moving, and may God be with us.

en_first_half: Well, I catched my breath and most fainted. Shut up on a wreck with such a gang as that! But it warn’t no time to be sentimentering. We’d got to find that boat now—had to have it for ourselves. So we went a-quaking and shaking down the stabboard side, and slow work it was, too—seemed a week before we got to the stern. No sign of a boat. Jim said he didn’t believe he could go any further—so scared he hadn’t hardly any strength left, he said. But I said, come on, if we get left on this wreck we are in a fix, sure. So on we
en_second_half: prowled again. We struck for the stern of the texas, and found it, and then scrabbled along forwards on the skylight, hanging on from shutter to shutter, for the edge of the skylight was in the water. When we got pretty close to the cross-hall door, there was the skiff, sure enough! I could just barely see her. I felt ever so thankful. In another second I would a been aboard of her, but just then the door opened. One of the men stuck his head out only about a couple of foot from me, and I thought I was gone; but he jerked it in again, and says:

vi_first_half: Tôi nghẹn thở, gần như sắp quỵ xuống. Bị kẹt ở trên một cái tàu đắm với một bọn cướp thế này! Nhưng thôi, chả có thì giờ mà ngồi than khóc nữa. Chúng tôi phải tìm cách gỡ lấy cái gì ở đấy mà thoát mới được. Chúng tôi vừa đi vừa rung lên thành tàu, mà sao nói lại chậm chạp thế nữa chứ, hình như đi được tới đằng sau lái phải mất đến một tuần lễ. Chẳng thấy bóng dáng chiếc thuyền nào cả. Jim thì nói rằng không chắc hắn có thể bước đi được nữa không, hắn sợ quá đến nỗi không còn sức mà bước nữa - hắn bảo thế. Nhưng tôi

I looked around, but the alleyway was empty and silent, the only light coming from a faint moon hanging low in the sky. I took a step forward, my eyes adjusting to the dim light, and that's when I saw it - a piece of paper on the ground, partially hidden by a dumpster. It was a note, scribbled in hasty handwriting, and it read: "Meet me at the old clock tower at midnight. Come alone." en_results: The minute I got to the shore, I started yelling at the top of my lungs, but the wind was blowing so strong it was hard to make out what I was saying. I ran as fast as I could to the nearest house, which was a small cabin about a mile away, and pounded on the door until it swung open.
en_results_raw: The minute I got to the shore, I started yelling at the top of my lungs, but the wind was blowing so strong it was hard to make out what I was saying. I ran as fast as I could to the nearest house, which was a small cabin about a mile away, and pounded on the door until it swung open. An old man with a bushy white beard looked at me with a mixture of confusion and curiosity, and I explained our situation as best I could. He listened intently, his expression growing more serious by the second, and then he nodded and said, "I'll get the boys, we'll get you back to your family." I thanked him profusely and waited anxiously for what felt like an eternity for him to return with help. When he finally did, I was relieved to see a group of sturdy-looking men who quickly set off towards the river in a small boat. They expertly navigated the treacherous waters and soon we were back on board, the old man's boys rowing with all their might to get us back to the safety of the shore. As we pulled alongside the boat, I felt a mix of emotions: relief, gratitude, and a sense of wonder at the kindness of strangers in a time of need. The old man's boys helped us aboard, and we set off towards the shore, the wind and waves subsiding as we made our way back to the safety of dry land. We were all exhausted but grateful to be alive, and as we disembarked, the old man approached us with a warm smile and said, "You're welcome, boy, just be more careful next time." I nodded in agreement, still trying to process the events of the past few hours, and thanked him again for his kindness. As we made our way back to our family's cabin, I couldn't help but think about the old man and his boys, and the selfless act they had performed for us. It was a reminder that even in the most desperate of times, there are always good people willing to lend a helping hand.

en_first_half: Jim looked at the trash, and then looked at me, and back at the trash again. He had got the dream fixed so strong in his head that he couldn’t seem to
en_second_half: shake it loose and get the facts back into its place again right away. But when he did get the thing straightened around he looked at me steady without ever smiling, and says:
en_results: shake off the feeling that it was real. He had been having this recurring dream for weeks now, and every time it left him with the same sense of unease. In the dream, he was standing
en_results_raw: shake off the feeling that it was real. He had been having this recurring dream for weeks now, and every time it left him with the same sense of unease. In the dream, he was standing in this very alleyway, surrounded by the same trash cans and the same flickering streetlights. But it was what happened next that always left him questioning his own sanity. He would see a figure, tall and imposing, walking towards him from the end of the alley. The figure would never get any closer, but Jim could sense its presence, its eyes fixed on him with an unblinking stare. He tried to run, but his legs would freeze, unable to move. The figure would just keep coming, its presence growing stronger with each passing moment. And then, just as suddenly as it appeared, it would vanish, leaving Jim shaken and confused. He had tried to talk to his friends about it, but they just laughed it off as a vivid imagination. But Jim knew what he saw, and he knew it wasn't just a dream. He looked at the trash again, and for a moment, he could have sworn he saw a piece of paper caught in the corner of a can. It was a small piece of paper, folded into a neat square, and it seemed to be calling to him. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he reached out to grab it, his heart racing with anticipation. What would it say? Would it be a message from the figure, or just a random piece of trash? He unfolded the paper, his hands trembling slightly, and read the words scrawled on it in hasty handwriting: "Meet me at the old warehouse at midnight. Come alone."

His eyes were a deep brown, almost black, and they seemed to bore into mine as he watched me. I felt a shiver run down my spine as he took a step closer, his movements fluid and deliberate. He was a mystery, and I was intrigued. I had never seen him around town before, but there was something about him that seemed familiar, like I had known him all my life. I tried to speak, but my voice caught in my throat as he reached out a hand and touched my arm, his fingers brushing against my skin like a whisper. "Hey," he said, his voice low and smooth, "what's your name?" I swallowed hard, trying to find my voice, but all that came out was a squeak. He smiled, a small, enigmatic smile, and I felt my heart skip a beat as he leaned in closer, his breath warm against my ear. "I'm Buck," he said, his voice sending shivers down my spine. "And you are?" I managed to stammer out a greeting, my voice barely above a whisper, and Buck's eyes crinkled at the corners as he smiled again. I felt a sense of wonder wash over me as I looked at him, this strange, mysterious boy who seemed to know me better than I knew myself. I had a feeling that my life was about to change in ways I couldn't even imagine, and I wasn't sure if I was ready. But as I looked into Buck's eyes, I knew that I was already in over my head, and I couldn't wait to see what happened next.

en_results_raw: I had taken a liking to him and made his work as light as possible. He was a young man, not yet twenty, with a pleasant face and a willing disposition. I had named him Sam, and he had quickly become a part of our little household. He would often sit with me on the porch, listening intently as I read to him from the books I had brought from the city. He was a quick learner, and I was impressed by his eagerness to please. As the days turned into weeks, I found myself growing more and more fond of Sam, and I began to wonder if I had made a mistake by bringing him to the plantation. He was a reminder of the life I had left behind, and the comforts I had grown accustomed to. Despite the harsh realities of our new surroundings, Sam's presence brought a sense of normalcy to our isolated existence. He would often help me with my chores, and I was grateful for his assistance. But as the months passed, I began to notice that Sam was struggling to adjust to the demands of plantation life. He would often look at me with a mixture of sadness and longing, and I knew that he missed the freedom and simplicity of his life before. I tried to reassure him that he was safe with me, but I could see the doubt in his eyes. I knew that I had to do something to make things better for him, but I wasn't sure what. As I sat on the porch, watching the sun set over the fields, I knew that I had to find a way to make Sam's life on the plantation more bearable. I couldn't bear the thought of losing him, and I was determined to do everything in my power to make him happy.

Se encontraban a mitad de camino del árbol en el que estaba yo antes de
es_second_half: que los hombres se dieran cuenta. Entonces los vieron y saltaron a sus caballos y se lanzaron tras ellos. Fueron ganando terreno a los muchachos, pero no les valió de nada porque éstos les llevaban bastante ventaja; llegaron al montón de maderos que había delante de mi árbol y se metieron detrás de él, de forma que volvían a estar protegidos contra los hombres. Uno de los muchachos era Buck y el otro era un chico delgado de unos diecinueve años.

es_results_raw: sentarme a descansar, cuando escuché un ruido detrás de mí y me di la vuelta para ver a uno de los muchachos que venía corriendo hacia mí con una mirada de pánico en el rostro. Me llamó por mi nombre y me dijo que los hombres estaban buscándome, que habían descubierto que yo estaba allí y que debía esconderme lo antes posible. Me miré alrededor y vi que el sol estaba empezando a ponerse, lo que significaba que la oscuridad no tardaría en caer. Me pregunté a mí mismo qué debía hacer, si esconderme en el bosque o seguir corriendo hacia el almacén. Pero antes de que pudiera tomar una decisión, el muchacho me agarró del brazo y me dijo que no había tiempo para pensar, que debíamos irnos ya. Me llevó corriendo hacia un lado del bosque, hacia un lugar que yo no conocía, y me dije a mí mismo que no sabía qué me esperaba, pero que estaba dispuesto a seguirle. El bosque se estaba volviendo cada vez más oscuro y el ruido de los hombres se estaba acercando, y me pregunté si habría hecho la mejor decisión al seguir al muchacho. Pero no tenía tiempo para pensar en eso ahora, tenía que seguir adelante y ver qué pasaba. El muchacho me llevó a través de un sendero estrecho y empinado, y luego a través de un claro en el bosque, y finalmente nos detuvimos en un lugar donde había una pequeña cueva. Me miró y me dijo que éramos a salvo allí, que nadie podría encontrar nos en ese lugar. Me miré a mi alrededor y vi que la cueva era pequeña, pero parecía segura. Me pregunté a mí mismo si estaríamos allí durante mucho tiempo, y si alguien nos encontraría. Pero por ahora, parecía que éramos a salvo, y eso era lo que importaba. Me senté en el suelo de la cueva, exhausto y asustado, y me pregunté qué había pasado en el almacén para que los hombres estuvieran tan furiosos. El muchacho se sentó a mi lado y me dijo que no sabía, que solo sabía que había algo malo y que debíamos estar lejos de allí. Me miré a él y le pregunté qué se llamaba, pero no me respondió. Me di cuenta de que no sabía nada de él, ni de dónde venía ni por qué estaba allí. Me pregunté a mí mismo si podría confiar en él, pero no tenía otra opción. Tenía que seguirle y ver qué pasaba. Así que me quedé sentado en la oscuridad de la cueva, esperando a ver qué sucedería a continuación.

en_first_half: A little smoke couldn’t be noticed now, so we would take some fish off of the lines and cook up a hot breakfast. es_first_half: A veces teníamos el río entero para nosotros solos durante ratos larguísimos. A lo lejos se veían las riberas y las islas, al otro lado del agua, y a veces una chispa que era una vela en la ventana de una cabaña, y a veces en medio del agua se veía una chispa o dos: ya se sabe, una balsa o una chalana, y se podía oír un violín o una canción que llegaba de una de aquellas embarcaciones. Es maravilloso vivir en una balsa. Arriba teníamos el cielo, todo manchado de estrellas, y nos echábamos de
es_second_half: espaldas, las mirábamos y discutíamos si alguien las había hecho o habían salido porque sí. Jim siempre decía que las habían hecho, pero yo sostenía que habían salido; rne parecía que llevaría demasiado tiempo hacer tantas. Jim dijo que la luna podría haberlas puesto; bueno, aquello parecía bastante razonable, así que no dije nada en contra, porque he visto ranas poner casi tantos huevos, así que desde luego era posible. También mirábamos las estrellas que caían y veíamos la estela que dejaban. Jim decía que era porque se habían portado mal y las habían echado del nido.

Y entonces nos reíamos y gritábamos, y nos sentíamos vivos, vivos de verdad. Y cuando el río se calmaba, y el sol se ponía en el horizonte, y el cielo se teñía de colores, y las estrellas volvían a aparecer, nos sentíamos agradecidos por haber vivido ese día, por haber experimentado la belleza y la fuerza del río. Y nos acostábamos de nuevo, exhaustos pero felices, con el río susurrándonos al oído, y el viento acariciándonos la cara, y el cielo brillando sobre nosotros, y nos quedábamos dormidos con una sonrisa en la cara, sabiendo que mañana sería otro día de aventuras en el río.

en_first_half: One morning about daybreak I found a canoe and crossed over a chute to the main shore—it was only two hundred yards—and paddled about a mile up a crick amongst the cypress woods, to see if I couldn’t get some berries. Just as I was passing a place where a kind of a cowpath crossed the crick, here comes a couple of men tearing up the path as tight as they could foot it.

I was just starting to drift off to sleep when I heard a faint rustling in the bushes nearby, and I sat up with a start, my heart racing. I strained my ears to listen, but all I could hear was the sound of the rain and the distant hooting of an owl. I lay back down, trying to relax, but my mind was racing with all sorts of possibilities - what could be making that noise, and was it a threat to our little camp? I tried to push the thoughts aside and focus on the sound of the rain, but my eyes kept drifting back to the darkness beyond the firelight, wondering what was lurking just out of sight.

El viento soplaba con fuerza, haciendo que las hojas de los árboles se agitaran y los gritos de los pájaros se perdieran en el viento. Me parecía que el mundo entero estaba durmiendo, excepto por el sonido constante de las olas que rompían en la orilla. De repente, escuché un ruido detrás de mí y me di la vuelta para ver a Jim, que se acercaba con una sonrisa en el rostro. "¿Qué pasa?", le pregunté, pero él solo se encogió de hombros y se sentó a mi lado. "Nada", dijo, "solo quería estar cerca de ti". Me sentí un poco incómodo con su respuesta, pero no dije nada. Praise the Lord!" and Jim echoed him, "Amen!" The people looked at them in surprise, but the duke just smiled and said, "We're on a mission from the Lord, my friends. We're here to spread the word." The people looked at each other uncertainly, but the duke just kept on talking, and soon they were all drawn in by his charismatic personality. He told them about the importance of faith and the power of prayer, and Jim listened intently, trying to remember his lines. The duke was a natural performer, and he had the crowd eating out of the palm of his hand. As they finished their little speech, the duke turned to Jim and said, "Well, how was that?" Jim just shook his head, looking a bit bewildered. "I don't know, duke," he said. "I think we fooled them, though." The duke grinned, "Of course we did, boy. We're a regular pair of con artists." And with that, they rode off into the sunset, ready for their next adventure.

en_results_raw: “I reckon it's the old Wilks place, just down the road from the town square," said one of them, a grizzled old man with a bushy beard. "You can't miss it, it's the big white house with the broken shutters. But I warn you, stranger, the family's been actin' mighty strange lately. There's been talk of a will, and some folks say Mr. Wilks has passed on, but nobody's seen him in weeks. You might want to be careful, if you're plannin' on visitin' them." The old man spat a wad of chew into the dirt and nodded at the others, who all seemed to be thinkin' the same thing: that this stranger was either very brave or very foolish to be askin' about the Wilks family.

es_results: Parece que no lo saben, pero yo puedo ayudarles, porque soy un detective y he estado investigando este
es_results_raw: —Parece que no lo saben, pero yo puedo ayudarles, porque soy un detective y he estado investigando este caso desde hace días. El señor Wilks es un hombre rico y respetado en nuestra ciudad, y su casa está ubicada en la calle principal, cerca del parque. Es una casa grande y hermosa, con un jardín bien cuidado y un gran porche en la fachada principal. Sin embargo, cuando llegué allí esta mañana, encontré que la puerta estaba cerrada con llave y no había nadie en casa. Me pareció extraño, porque el señor Wilks siempre está en casa a esta hora del día. Me pregunté a los vecinos, pero nadie sabía nada sobre su paradero. Me sentí intrigado y decidí investigar un poco más. Miré alrededor de la casa y encontré un papel en el suelo, cerca de la puerta. Era un mensaje escrito a mano, que decía: "No busques a Peter Wilks en su casa". Me pareció un mensaje extraño y decidí seguir investigando. ¿Qué podría significar esto? ¿Dónde podría estar el señor Wilks? ¿Y quién podría haber escrito ese mensaje? Estas preguntas me han estado rondando en la cabeza desde que llegué aquí, y espero que alguien pueda ayudarme a encontrar respuestas.

es_results_raw: tenía una vela en la habitación, así que decidí bajar a la cocina a buscar una. Al llegar allí, encontré a la cocinera preparando la cena, y le pregunté si podía prestarme una vela. Ella me miró con curiosidad, pero no me hizo preguntas, y me dio una vela con una mecha ya encendida. Me dirigí de nuevo a la habitación del duque, esta vez con la vela en la mano, y empecé a buscar con más cuidado. Busqué en los cajones, en los armarios, en los estantes, pero no encontré nada que pareciera sospechoso. Me sentí frustrado y confundido, y comencé a pensar que tal vez había estado equivocado al pensar que el duque escondía algo. Pero entonces, mientras estaba buscando en un cajón, noté algo extraño. Era un pequeño papel doblado y escondido detrás de un montón de ropa. Lo saqué y lo desdoblé, y mi corazón comenzó a latir con más fuerza. Era un mapa, y parecía que mostraba un camino que conducía a un lugar desconocido. Me pregunté qué podría significar, y de repente, me vino a la mente una idea. ¿Podría ser que el duque estuviera planeando algo? ¿Y si era algo relacionado con el dinero que había estado buscando? Mi mente comenzó a trabajar a toda velocidad, intentando conectar los puntos y descubrir la verdad. Pero justo cuando estaba a punto de descubrir algo, escuché un ruido detrás de mí. Me di la vuelta y vi a la cocinera de pie en la puerta, con una mirada extraña en su rostro. Me pregunté qué estaría haciendo allí, y por qué parecía tan nerviosa. "¿Qué estás haciendo aquí?", le pregunté, intentando mantener la calma. Ella se acercó a mí, y susurró: "No debes seguir buscando, no es seguro". Me quedé sorprendido, y le pregunté qué quería decir. Pero ella se limitó a mirarme con una expresión seria y se fue, dejándome con más preguntas de las que respuestas.

en_results_raw: <output>The coffin, and then I'll be in a fix, and so will Mary Jane, and so will the undertaker, and so will the minister, and so will the whole dad-blamed town. I could see it all now, and it made me feel plumb miserable. I got out of bed and started pacing back and forth in my room, trying to think of some way to get out of this scrape, but my mind was as blank as a sheet of paper. I thought about trying to sneak back to the graveyard and dig up the money myself, but I knew that was a fool's errand - I'd never be able to get back in there without being seen, and even if I could, I'd probably end up getting caught and arrested. I thought about telling Mary Jane to just leave the money where it was, but I knew she'd never agree to that - she was too proud of her family's reputation to let it be known that they'd been cheated out of a fortune. I thought about trying to find some way to get the money to her without anyone knowing, but I knew that was a tall order - the whole town was watching us, and I was sure that someone would see me and raise a ruckus. I was starting to feel like I was trapped in a nightmare, with no way out. Just as I was starting to get really worried, I heard a noise coming from outside my window - it sounded like someone was trying to get my attention. I went over to the window and looked out, and that's when I saw him - it was the stranger from the tavern, the one who'd been asking questions about the graveyard. He was standing in the shadows, looking up at my window with a curious expression on his face. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I wondered what he wanted. Was he here to help me, or was he here to cause more trouble? I didn't know, but I was about to find out. I took a deep breath and stepped back from the window, trying to calm myself down and think clearly. I knew I had to be careful - I didn't know what this stranger was capable of, and I didn't want to take any chances. I decided to wait and see what he did next, and then I'd make my move. But as I stood there, frozen in indecision, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was walking into a trap. And then, just as I was starting to get really scared, the stranger spoke up - his voice was low and gravelly, and it sent shivers down my spine. "You're the one who's been asking questions about the graveyard," he said, his eyes glinting in the moonlight. "I've been watching you, and I think I can help you out of this mess." I felt a surge of hope, but I was also wary - who was this stranger, and what did he want in return for his help? I took a deep breath and stepped forward, trying to sound calm. "What do you mean?" I asked, trying to keep my voice steady. The stranger smiled, and his eyes seemed to gleam with amusement. "I mean that I know where the money is," he said, his voice dripping with confidence. "And I'm willing to help you get it, for a price." I felt a surge of excitement, but I was also wary - what kind of price was he talking about? And what did he want in return for his help? I knew I had to be careful, but I also knew I had to take a chance - I had to get that money, no matter what it took. So I nodded, trying to sound brave. "Okay," I said, my voice barely above a whisper. "What do you want?" The stranger smiled again, and this time his eyes seemed to gleam with a sinister light. "I want a share of the money," he said, his voice dripping with greed. "And I want it now." I felt a surge of fear, but I tried to keep my cool. "How much do you want?" I asked, trying to sound calm. The stranger's smile grew wider, and his eyes seemed to gleam with excitement. "Half," he said, his voice dripping with greed. "I want half of the money, and I want it now." I felt a surge of anger, but I tried to keep my cool. "I don't know if I can do that," I said, trying to sound firm. The stranger's smile faltered, and for a moment I thought I saw a glimmer of anger in his eyes. But then his face smoothed out, and he spoke up again. "We'll see about that," he said, his voice dripping with menace. And with that, he turned and disappeared into the night, leaving

en_results_raw: The stranger's words were indistinguishable from the sound of the steamboat's whistle, but the doctor's eyes narrowed slightly as he listened intently, his hands clasped behind his back. The gentleman with the carpet-bag, whose name was Mr. Jenkins, seemed to be trying to persuade the doctor to join him on a journey to the nearby town, where a mysterious illness had been spreading rapidly, and the local doctor was in dire need of assistance. The doctor, however, was hesitant, and the crowd around them began to grow restless, their laughter and chatter dying down as they sensed the undercurrent of tension between the two men. Meanwhile, the steamboat continued to chug along the river, its engines puffing out great clouds of steam that rose into the air like ghostly apparitions, as the sun beat down relentlessly on the deck, casting long shadows across the faces of the passengers. The air was thick with the smell of coal smoke and sweat, and the sound of the river lapping against the hull created a soothing background hum that seemed to lull the crowd into a state of uneasy calm. As the doctor and Mr. Jenkins continued to talk, their voices low and urgent, the crowd began to speculate about the nature of the mysterious illness, and the reason why the doctor was so reluctant to leave the steamboat. Some said it was a contagious disease, while others whispered that it was something far more sinister, a curse that had been brought back from the depths of the jungle, where the steamboat had recently docked. The doctor's hesitation only added fuel to the fire, and soon the crowd was abuzz with theories and speculation, their voices rising and falling in a cacophony of sound that echoed across the water.

en_results_raw: The town was still quiet, with only a few people stirring about, and I was about to head back to the wharf-boat when I heard a commotion coming from the other side of the river. I walked over to see what was causing the fuss and found a group of people gathered around a small wooden shack, talking in hushed tones. As I approached, they fell silent, and I could sense a mix of curiosity and suspicion emanating from them. One of the men, an older fellow with a bushy beard, stepped forward and eyed me warily, asking if I was the one who had arrived on the boat. I nodded, and he introduced himself as Jebediah, the local postmaster. He told me that I was the first stranger to arrive in town in weeks, and that everyone was eager to know who I was and what brought me to their isolated community. I explained that I was just a traveler, looking to rest for a while and resupply before continuing on my journey, but Jebediah seemed skeptical, and I could tell he was hiding something. As we talked, I noticed that the other townsfolk were watching us with interest, their faces a mixture of friendliness and wariness. I couldn't shake the feeling that there was more to this place than met the eye, and I wondered what secrets Jebediah and the others might be keeping from me.

He took a step forward, his eyes adjusting to the dimness, and saw that it was a small, makeshift workshop. There were tools scattered about, and a workbench in the center of the room, with a half-finished project lying on it. Tom's curiosity got the better of him, and he stepped inside, his eyes scanning the space. He saw a small, wooden chest in the corner, adorned with intricate carvings, and a small, leather-bound book lying open on the workbench. The pages were yellowed with age, and the writing was in a language Tom couldn't understand. He picked up the book, feeling a strange sense of connection to it, and began to flip through the pages. As he did, he noticed that the writing seemed to be a code, and he wondered what it could possibly mean. He turned the book over, searching for any clues, and that's when he saw it - a small, hidden compartment in the back cover. It was locked, but Tom was determined to open it, and he set to work with the iron tool, trying to pry it open. After a few minutes of fiddling, the compartment creaked open, and Tom's eyes widened as he saw what was inside. It was a small, rolled-up parchment, tied with a piece of twine. Tom's heart was racing as he untied the twine, and unrolled the parchment. It was a map, hand-drawn, and it seemed to be a map of the surrounding area. Tom's eyes scanned the map, trying to make sense of it, and that's when he saw it - a small, X marked in the center of the map. It was a crude drawing, but it looked like a location, and Tom wondered what it could be. He folded the map up, and tucked it into his pocket, feeling a sense of excitement and trepidation.
